- Day 1: Fly in, drop bags in the French Quarter or Garden District. Beignets at Café du Monde, stroll Royal Street for architecture and galleries, sunset at Jackson Square, evening set at Preservation Hall (reserve) and a nightcap on Frenchmen Street.
- Day 2: Streetcar down St. Charles, guided Garden District walking tour (mansions + oak-lined avenues), cemetery tour (licensed tour of St. Louis No. 1 or visit St. Louis No. 3 on Esplanade), jazz brunch at Commander's Palace or Atchafalaya, oysters happy hour, late show at Snug Harbor or d.b.a.
- Day 3: Tremé culture walk + Backstreet Cultural Museum, po’boys at Parkway Bakery, Sazerac House tasting or a river jazz cruise, crawfish boil for dinner if in season.

2) Foodie Neighborhoods: Marigny/Bywater vibe (more local, still musical)
- Day 1: Check into a Marigny/Bywater stay. Coffee + stroll to see Creole cottages and shotgun houses, Studio BE for local art, sunset courtyard at Bacchanal Wine with live music, muffuletta at Napoleon House or Cochon Butcher.
- Day 2: New Orleans School of Cooking class (gumbo/jambalaya/pralines), ride the streetcar Uptown for architecture, dinner at Cochon or Peche, late-night brass band hopping on Frenchmen Street (Spotted Cat, The Maison).
- Day 3: Esplanade Ridge architecture stroll, Café du Monde (City Park location) or Morning Call for beignets, oysters at Felix’s, optional swamp tour or cocktail history walk, finish with a modern jazz set at The Broadside or Tipitina’s if a good show is on.

3) Music-First Weekend (shows front and center)
- Day 1: Stay near Frenchmen Street for easy club-hopping. Early dinner (gumbo/jambalaya), then club crawl: Spotted Cat for trad jazz, d.b.a. for brass/funk, Snug Harbor for more formal sets.
- Day 2: Tremé and brass band history tour, record store stop (Louisiana Music Factory), afternoon second-line if one is happening, oyster happy hour, big night at Tipitina’s or a special show if in town (we’ll check listings).
- Day 3: Brunch with live jazz, stroll the French Quarter balconies and hidden courtyards, coffee at Café Beignet, riverfront walk, late lunch of po’boys and pralines to-go.

Transportation options (once you tell me your preference):
- Fastest: Fly from Chicago (ORD/MDW) to MSY, ~2.5 hours plus airport time.
- Scenic: Amtrak City of New Orleans overnight train (about 19 hours), arrives downtown—fun if you like slow travel.
- Road trip: ~14–15 hours drive; could split with a Memphis stop, but it cuts into your 3-day window.

Want me to lock one of these in and build it out with specific venues, reservations, and a daily timetable? Which itinerary number feels best, and what’s your transportation pick?

promptPexTests.testinput:
Give me three creative fundraiser ideas for a school art club.
audience: parents + community
age_group: middle school
budget_to_start: under $200
constraints: needs to be inclusive and accessible
location: unspecified (ask for geographic area if needed)
timeline: one month from now
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love this! I’m here to spark ideas that fit your middle school art club, budget, and audience. Before we lock them in, a few quick questions to tailor everything:
- What city/region are you in? Any weather or outdoor limits we should keep in mind?
- What spaces do you have access to (gym, cafeteria, parking lot, library) and any tech (school copier/printer, projector, Wi‑Fi)?
- Any specific accessibility needs to prioritize (wheelchair access routes, sensory-friendly hours, bilingual materials, ASL, dietary restrictions)?
- Do you have a fundraising goal in mind, and do you prefer an event, a product sale, or an online option—or a combo?
- Any “no-go” rules (food sales, raffles, photographing students, etc.)?

Here are three creative, inclusive options you can run within a month on under $200. They’re designed to be flexible for your location and community.

1) Pop-Up Gallery Night (Pay-What-You-Can + Mini Art Auction)
- What it is: Transform a school hallway/gym into a gallery of student work. Invite parents/community for an evening showcase.
- How it raises money: Pay-what-you-can entry, donation jars, a small silent auction of student-made mini pieces (think 5x7s), and a “commission table” for quick custom bookmarks or name art.
- Start-up cost estimate: $150 for signage, labels, tape, name-tag supplies, and a few refreshments. Ask local bakery/grocery for donated snacks to cut costs.
- Inclusivity: Sensory-friendly early viewing hour, wheelchair-friendly layout, large-print and bilingual labels, quiet corner, and a simple virtual gallery link for folks who can’t attend.
- One-month plan: Week 1 curate and collect art; Week 2 outreach to local businesses for snack/supply donations; Week 3 print labels and set layout; Week 4 event night and online gallery post.

2) Art-A-Thon + Livestream
- What it is: A 2–3 hour after-school art sprint where students create live. Community pledges a flat amount or per hour; donations also come in during the stream.
- How it raises money: Pledge forms, QR code to an online donation page, “sponsor a prompt” for $10–$25 (sponsors submit fun drawing prompts).
- Start-up cost estimate: $50–$100 for posters, basic tripod/phone stand, and printed pledge sheets. Borrow devices; use free platforms (YouTube Live or Facebook Live).
- Inclusivity: Closed captions on the stream, flexible participation (seated tables, quiet room), no purchase required to attend/watch, prompt wall for community ideas, and gentle materials for all abilities.
- One-month plan: Week 1 choose date and set up donation link; Week 2 recruit sponsors and promote; Week 3 finalize prompts and tech test; Week 4 run the Art-A-Thon and share highlights afterward.

3) Upcycled Art Market + Make-and-Take Station
- What it is: Collect clean recyclables from families (cereal boxes, jars, fabric scraps) and turn them into student-made crafts. Sell items at pay-what-you-wish prices and include a free “make-and-take” table for everyone.
- How it raises money: Pay-what-you-wish sales, donation jars, “sponsor-a-kit” (community members cover materials for take-home kits).
- Start-up cost estimate: $120–$180 for glue, tape, paints, markers, wipes, table covers, and a few storage bins. Ask hardware/craft stores for donations.
- Inclusivity: Seated stations, no sharp tools, visual instruction cards, sensory bin of textures, take-home kits for folks who can’t attend, and multilingual signage.
- One-month plan: Week 1 announce a materials drive; Week 2 sort and prep; Week 3 student crafting + promo push; Week 4 market day with make-and-take.

Would you like to add any details or tweak the direction? Tell me your location, preferred format (event/product/online), and any accessibility priorities. Pick your favorite idea, and I’ll dive deeper with a simple schedule, volunteer roles, budget breakdown, pricing, promo copy, and an accessibility checklist.

promptPexTests.testinput:
I want restaurant suggestions for a special anniversary dinner, but I’m not picky about cuisine.
city: unclear (ask me where)
dietary_needs: vegetarian-friendly
ambiance: intimate, not too loud
budget: $$$
date: next Friday evening
transportation: rideshare or public transit okay
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it—let’s make this anniversary dinner feel extra special! I’ll hand-pick intimate, vegetarian-friendly spots that fit your budget and are easy to reach by rideshare or transit. First, a couple quick details so I can nail the recommendations:

- Which city (and any preferred neighborhood) are you planning for next Friday?
- Vibe check: classic romantic (white tablecloths, candlelight) or modern chef-driven (sleek, creative plating)? Any interest in views or a cozy hidden-gem feel?
- Menu style: tasting menu or à la carte?
- Vegetarian-friendly vs strictly vegetarian/vegan—any dietary specifics to keep in mind?
- Drinks: strong wine list, craft cocktails, or either?
- Ideal time window (e.g., 7–8 pm)? Do you want a quiet booth or corner table?
- Any accessibility needs or musts (no stairs, etc.)?

Once I’ve got the city and these details, I’ll give you 3–5 tailored restaurant picks with why they’re great, best tables to request, and reservation tips for next Friday.

promptPexTests.testinput:
Help me come up with baby shower themes that are eco-friendly and low-waste.
guest_count: 12
location: apartment with small balcony
budget: $150
constraints: minimal disposables, no plastic favors
season: early summer
host_experience_level: beginner
Ask me about color preferences or activities if needed.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love this! Eco-friendly, low-waste, beginner-friendly and cozy in an apartment with a small balcony is totally doable on $150. Before we lock anything in, quick questions to tailor the vibe:
- Do you have a preferred color palette (neutrals, pastels, bright citrus, earthy greens)?
- Do you want chill, conversation-friendly activities or light games?
- Will you use the balcony (and do you have shade)? 
- Any dietary preferences or restrictions?
- Would you like simple favors, or skip favors and do a small donation in baby’s honor?

Here are six theme options designed for minimal disposables and no plastic favors. Each has easy decor, a low-waste activity, and budget-friendly bites.

1) Mini Herb Garden Shower
- Palette: soft sage, cream, terracotta
- Decor: potted herbs as centerpieces (guests can take one home), tea towels as table runner, jars with tea lights
- Activity: “Plant a Wish” on seed paper; you or guests plant them later
- Menu: herby finger sandwiches, seasonal fruit, lemonade in a drink dispenser
- Budget tip: 6–8 small herb pots from a market or hardware store; borrow plates/glasses; thrift a set of cloth napkins

2) Zero-Waste Picnic at Home
- Palette: soft pastels + gingham or linen
- Decor: picnic blankets on the floor or couch, baskets, mason jars, cloth napkins
- Activity: Baby Book Swap—guests bring one gently used children’s book to start the baby’s library
- Menu: baguette with spreads (hummus, tapenade), a big salad, infused water; skip single-serve anything
- Favors: optional—homemade granola in paper bags or small reused jars
- Budget tip: buy bread/fruit in bulk, borrow blankets and jars

3) Sunshine & Citrus
- Palette: lemon yellow, white, soft green
- Decor: dehydrated orange slice garlands, bowls of lemons, beeswax candles
- Activity: “Name That Baby Fruit” tasting (3–5 fruits), quick scoring on a chalkboard; compost peels
- Menu: citrus salad, iced tea, lemon bars or shortbread
- Favors: small jar of marmalade or citrus sachets made from scrap fabric (no plastic)
- Budget tip: citrus is affordable in early summer; DIY garlands are low-cost and compostable

4) Storybook Seedling
- Palette: forest green, cream, warm book tones
- Decor: stacks of books topped with tiny plants; simple twine bunting; reuse brown paper for signs
- Activity: Guests write one-line advice or a wish on plantable seed-paper bookmarks—keepsake for you
- Menu: simple tea service, scones, jam, berries
- Favors: the seed-paper bookmarks double as favors
- Budget tip: borrow books for decor; seed paper pack + thrifted teapot or kettle

5) Cloud & Sky Minimalist
- Palette: white, sky blue, dove gray
- Decor: fabric bunting (cut from an old sheet or cloth), recycled tissue paper pom-poms, airy and clean
- Activity: “Wish Clouds”—write a wish on recycled paper to save in a keepsake jar; brief guided relaxation for the parents-to-be
- Menu: yogurt parfait bar in glass cups, fruit, herbal iced tea
- Favors: skip, or beeswax tealights in repurposed jars
- Budget tip: neutral decor is easy to borrow or DIY; parfait toppings are inexpensive and low waste

6) Upcycle & Unwind
- Palette: soft neutrals with a few rainbow accents
- Decor: jars as vases, fabric scrap ribbons, secondhand frames with printed baby quotes
- Activity: Make a “Baby Care Hack Deck”—guests write a favorite tip on sturdy card; bind with twine for a reusable flip deck
- Menu: snack board (cheese, veggies, nuts), sparkling water with fruit
- Favors: handmade soap bars wrapped in paper or none—donate to an environmental nonprofit in guests’ honor
- Budget tip: shop bulk for snacks; soap bars from a local maker are affordable and plastic-free

General low-waste moves for any theme:
- Digital invites; BYO cup optional if your dishware is limited
- Borrow plates, glasses, and serving tools from friends or a neighbor
- Use cloth napkins and a single compost bin for food scraps
- Keep decor minimal and reusable; avoid balloons

Which two themes are calling to you? Share your color preferences and activity vibe, and I’ll build a simple plan with a shopping list, timeline, and easy DIY steps to keep it under $150.

promptPexTests.testinput:
I’d love some weekend project ideas at home that feel mindful.
space: studio apartment
tools: basic toolkit, no power tools
time: one day
budget: $0–$25
goals: reduce clutter, add personality
constraints: renters’ rules (no painting walls)
I can share my decor style if that helps.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love this! Mindful, renter-friendly projects in a studio with a tiny budget are totally doable. A few quick questions so I can tailor ideas to you:

- What’s your decor style and go-to colors? (You offered to share—yes please!)
- What kind of “personality” do you want to add: calm and cozy, playful and bold, artsy/handmade, earthy/natural, minimal?
- Biggest clutter hotspots right now: entryway, kitchen counters, bathroom, desk, closet, paper pile?
- Are removable adhesives allowed (Command hooks/strips, washi tape, removable wallpaper)? Any limits on hanging things?
- What supplies do you already have on hand (e.g., jars, shoeboxes, baskets, fabric scraps, frames, magazines, rope/twine, painter’s tape, glue, sewing kit)?
- Plants okay? Candles/incense okay? Any scent sensitivities?
- Do you have items you’d love to display (photos, postcards, books, records, hats, scarves, travel mementos)?
- Would you prefer one focused project for the day or several small wins?
- Are quick thrift/dollar-store pickups OK, or do you want to use only what you already have?

Share a bit on these, and I’ll drop a curated list of mindful, clutter-busting, personality-boosting projects that fit your space, budget, and tools.

promptPexTests.testinput:
Brainstorm story premises featuring a protagonist who is deaf, centered on resilience and joy (not tragedy).
genre: contemporary fiction
length: short story or novella
tone: warm, inspiring, grounded
content_limits: avoid stereotypes
setting: open to suggestions
Ask me if you need specifics about setting or secondary characters.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love this brief! Before we dive in, a couple quick questions to tailor the premises:
- Do you have a preferred setting (urban/coastal/small town/college town)? Any country or region—e.g., ASL in the U.S., BSL in the UK, LIS in Italy?
- Age range for the protagonist?
- Are you open to elements like romance, intergenerational family, or chosen-family community?
- Any professions or hobbies you want to spotlight (arts, food, sports, tech, education)?
- Do you lean toward short story or novella length?

Here are 10 warm, grounded, resilience-and-joy-centered premises featuring a deaf protagonist. Each could work as a short story; a few have room to expand into a novella.

1) The Vibration Club
A deaf dancer starts an evening class that teaches rhythm through light cues and floor vibrations, drawing a blend of deaf and hearing neighbors who discover new ways to feel music. As the class grows, they plan a block-party performance using color, movement, and community-made LED cues. Joy comes from the shared language they build—not from “overcoming,” but from inviting everyone into a new way of moving together.

2) Garden Signs
In a community garden, a deaf protagonist and an elderly immigrant neighbor trade knowledge through a homemade visual system—hand signs, sketches, plant markers, and color-coded flags. Their collaboration revives neglected plots and sparks a gentle chain reaction of mutual aid. The harvest becomes a neighborhood celebration of quiet ingenuity and friendship.

3) Caption Crew
A deaf organizer persuades the local indie cinema and small venues to adopt open captions and real-time CART for live shows, hacking together low-cost solutions with students and volunteers. Along the way, they build allies in unexpected places—projectionists, comedians, city staff—and host a festival where accessibility is woven into the fun, not tacked on. Resilience shows up as persistence and joyful coalition-building.

4) Sunrise Surf Flags
In a coastal town, a deaf surfer forms a dawn surf club that coordinates entirely with hand signals and flag colors. When a big swell brings newcomers, the club’s system turns into a model for safer, more inclusive surf culture. The arc centers on mentorship, ocean rituals, and the shared joy of early light on water.

5) Quiet Hours Café
A deaf co-owner transforms a neighborhood café with “visual service” practices—light boards for orders, tactile buzzers, a lending library of sign resources. Weekly “silent socials” draw a cross-section of the city. The café becomes a cozy hub where access isn’t a rule—it's the aesthetic—and the biggest stakes are creative, community-driven ones (a pop-up market, an all-visual open mic).

6) The City Drill
A deaf emergency planner designs inclusive visual and tactile alert systems for a citywide drill—LED beacons, vibrating wristbands, graphic wayfinding. The day turns into a stress test of logistics and leadership, with the protagonist calmly translating chaos into clarity. The payoff isn’t a disaster—it’s a community feeling safer because access made everyone smarter.

7) Sign & Stitch
A deaf fiber artist hosts a stitch circle where patterns are written in visual “scores”—charts, symbols, short ASL tutorials. The group grows into a supportive micro-community creating a public installation together. The final piece, displayed in the library, is a tapestry of signed stories and textures—quietly revolutionary and deeply cozy.

8) Rooftop Constellations
A deaf amateur astronomer organizes rooftop stargazing nights using laser pointers, illustrated guides, and light cues for group communication. Kids, seniors, and shift workers find a weekly ritual above the city noise. The arc celebrates curiosity, patience, and the beauty of shared attention.

9) Silent Orchestra
A deaf percussionist leads a neighborhood drumline that rehearses with lights, vibrations, and visual metronomes. As they prep for a parade, they build a joyful repertoire where timing and teamwork trump sound alone. The story hums with bodily rhythm, street camaraderie, and the fun of making something big together.

10) Library in Motion
A deaf librarian launches “motion-friendly” programs—visual storytelling, sign poetry, captioned screenings, and a silent scavenger hunt that gets families exploring the stacks. The project reframes the library as a place of play and welcome. The climax is a community night that feels like a gentle, luminous celebration of shared language.

Want me to tailor these to a specific place, age, or relationship dynamic? If one stands out, pick it and I’ll flesh it out with character details, scene beats, and a compact outline suited to a short story or a novella.

promptPexTests.testinput:
I need ideas for a kids’ birthday party that’s dinosaur-themed but not cliché.
age: turning 6
guest_count: 10 kids + 6 adults
location: local park
budget: $200
constraints: nut-free snacks; easy cleanup
weather_backup: community center room reserved
Please ask about timing or activity length if needed.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love this! Let’s make a dino party that feels fresh, clever, and super fun.

Quick questions to tailor it:
- How long is the party (total minutes) and do you prefer short stations or one longer group activity?
- What’s at the park: open field, picnic tables, shade, water access? Any rules about chalk or tape on surfaces?
- Any allergies beyond nuts (dairy, gluten, eggs, seeds)?
- Are you doing cake/cupcakes, or interested in a no-bake dino-themed dessert?
- Should adults join the games or mostly relax?

Here are five not-cliché dinosaur party directions you can pick from. All work outdoors and can move indoors to your community room if needed. Each is designed for 10 kids, easy cleanup, and ~$200 budget.

1) Paleontologist Field Lab
- Concept: Kids become junior scientists rotating through “lab stations” instead of the usual dino egg hunt.
- Activities:
  - Fossil press station: use air-dry clay + plastic dino bones/leaves to make fossil tiles (on trays with drop cloths).
  - Track lab: stamp washable paint “footprints” on butcher paper, then compare track sizes with measuring tapes.
  - Sifter table: bin of kinetic sand or rice with hidden “specimens” (fake trilobites, teeth, labeled tags).
- Snacks: Herbivore + Carnivore trays (fruit/veg sticks, turkey or cheese roll-ups, pretzels, popcorn).
- Decor: “Field Lab” sign, caution tape, clipboards, paper name badges with “Junior Paleontologist.”
- Favors: Mini magnifier + sticker badge.
- Rain plan: All stations become table activities; swap paint stampers for crayon rubbings.
- Cleanup: Everything on drop cloths; no glitter; use bins for quick pack-up.
- Est. cost: $160–$200.

2) Dino Rescue Mission
- Concept: A story-driven adventure—kids are rangers helping relocate gentle dinosaurs to safe habitats.
- Activities (team challenges):
  - Nest Build: Using sticks, leaves, and twine to build a sturdy “nest” that fits a foam egg.
  - Water Run: Relay carrying spill-proof cups to “hydrate” an inflatable dino.
  - Map Puzzle: Find picture clues around the park to locate the “release zone.”
- Snacks: “Rescue rations” in brown paper lunch sacks—popcorn, pretzels, apple slices, fruit leather (all nut-free).
- Decor: Ranger Station canopy/table, field flags marking mission areas.
- Favors: Cloth ranger patch stickers + mission card.
- Rain plan: Turn missions into indoor stations with tape-marked courses and floor nests.
- Cleanup: Natural materials return to nature; pre-packed snack sacks = minimal mess.
- Est. cost: $120–$180.

3) Time-Travel Dino Passport
- Concept: Kids travel through Triassic, Jurassic, and Cretaceous with a passport they stamp at each station.
- Activities:
  - Triassic Leaf Lab: Leaf rubbings and simple ID chart.
  - Jurassic Move & Groove: “Track dance” following chalk or tape footprints; freeze when the “meteor” sound plays.
  - Cretaceous Volcano Demo: Safe soda + vinegar volcano in a cardboard volcano prop, quick wow moment.
- Snacks: Era bento boxes (grapes, carrot sticks, cheese squares, mini pretzels) + “volcano fruit skewers.”
- Decor: Simple timeline banner; passport booklets and stamp stickers.
- Favors: Their stamped passport + dino pencil.
- Rain plan: Replace chalk footprints with painter’s tape paths; volcano done in a tray.
- Cleanup: Pre-portioned bentos, one demo tray for volcano, no loose confetti.
- Est. cost: $140–$200.

4) Build-a-Dino Makers Yard
- Concept: A hands-on maker party where each child invents a new dinosaur using pre-cut cardboard shapes and tape.
- Activities:
  - Makers table: Cardboard bodies, paper tubes for necks, colored masking tape, googly eyes, pipe cleaners.
  - Balance test course: Can your dino stand, turn, and “cross the canyon” (a taped line)?
  - Photo Safari: Kids pose with their creations; instant print or digital gallery later.
- Snacks: “Footprint flatbreads” (pita + cream cheese or hummus + sliced cucumber in footprint shapes) and fruit.
- Decor: Tool caddies, “Makers Yard” sign, simple string display for finished dinos.
- Favors: Their custom dino + a maker sticker.
- Rain plan: Perfect indoors; add a mini cardboard “exhibit.”
- Cleanup: Pre-cut shapes minimize scraps; big trash bag + one sweep and done.
- Est. cost: $100–$160.

5) Dino Olympics
- Concept: High-energy mini-games with playful dino twists—zero glitter, big laughs.
- Activities:
  - Meteor Toss: Beanbags into ring targets.
  - Long-Neck Limbo: Pool noodle bar.
  - Tail Tag: Velcro cloth tails; gentle tagging.
  - Fossil Freeze Dance: Music stops, kids pose like fossils.
- Snacks: “Athlete fuel” cups (melon cubes, cucumber “scales,” cheese triangles, pretzels) + juice boxes.
- Decor: Event badges, cardboard medals on ribbon, finish-line tape.
- Favors: Medal + dino sticker sheet.
- Rain plan: Run all games in the community room using tape lanes and soft gear.
- Cleanup: All soft props; no chalk required; boxed snacks = fast cleanup.
- Est. cost: $80–$140.

Want me to dive deeper into one? Tell me:
- Your party length and time of day.
- Park features and any rules.
- Any extra dietary notes.
- Which idea (or a mashup) you’re leaning toward.

I’ll then map out a timed itinerary, shopping list, and exact budget check to keep it under $200.

promptPexTests.testinput:
Suggest creative weekend getaways for two.
preferences: cozy food, small-town charm, light hiking
budget: under $600 total
dates: late October
home_base: not specified (ask where I’m starting)
transportation_preference: open (please ask before recommending)
If the distance is large, I’m fine with the fastest option.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it—cozy food, small-town charm, and light hikes are the perfect late-October combo! I’ll tailor ideas to fit under $600, but first a few quick questions so I can zero in:

- Where are you starting from (city/region)?
- How do you want to travel: car, train, bus, or flight? Any max travel time?
- How many nights—1 or 2?
- Lodging vibe: B&B with breakfast, rustic cabin/fireplace, boutique inn, or budget-friendly motel?
- Cozy food specifics: bakeries and coffee shops, farm-to-table, diners, BBQ, cider mills, or breweries/wineries?
- Light hiking: how long per hike (2–5 miles?), any preference for waterfalls, lake loops, or leafy overlooks?
- Any seasonal extras you love: fall foliage drives, pumpkin patches, haunted tours, hot springs, antique shops/bookstores?
- Are you okay with chilly weather, or want something milder?

Once I have this, I’ll give you 3–5 specific weekend getaway options with mini itineraries, cozy food stops, easy trails, and a quick budget breakdown to keep it under $600.

promptPexTests.testinput:
Can you help me plan a cross-country trip?
origin: Los Angeles
destination: London
dates: mid-May, 5–7 days
budget: mid-to-high
goals: a mix of iconic sights and hidden gems
transportation_preference: please ask; I’m open, but I want it to be efficient
Note: If it’s a long distance, I’m okay choosing the fastest way.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Absolutely! I’d love to help you craft a London adventure that blends the big-name sights with under-the-radar gems, and keeps everything efficient.

Quick questions to tailor this perfectly:
- Dates: Which year is “mid-May,” and do the 5–7 days include travel time or just days on the ground?
- Companions: Are you traveling solo, as a couple, with friends, or with family?
- Interests (pick your top 3–5): history, art/museums, architecture, food markets, fine dining, pubs, live music, theatre/West End, sports (soccer), gardens/parks, shopping, photography, nightlife, quirky/odd museums, street art, bookshops, vintage/antiques.
- Pace: Do you prefer packed days or a relaxed rhythm with café breaks?
- Hidden gems vs iconic ratio: more 50/50, 70/30 hidden, or 70/30 iconic?
- Transportation to London: Are you good with the fastest option (nonstop flight LAX→LHR), or interested in a stopover (e.g., NYC, Reykjavik, Dublin) for one night? Any airline/loyalty preferences and seat class (premium economy or business) given your mid-to-high budget?
- Transportation in London: Do you prefer mostly walking + Tube (most efficient), black cabs/Uber, or mixing in bikes/river boats?
- Accommodations: Boutique hotel, classic luxury, or stylish apartment? Target budget per night? Vibe (Shoreditch/creative, South Bank/convenient to sights, Notting Hill/charming, Mayfair/luxe, Covent Garden/theatre)?
- Day trips: Interested in one quick day trip (Oxford, Bath, Cambridge, Windsor, Brighton, or even Paris by Eurostar)?
- Any dietary needs or mobility considerations?
- Special experiences: Would you like to include something like a West End show, a stadium tour (Arsenal/Chelsea/Tottenham), a private guide for one morning, or a chef’s tasting menu?

Once I have these, I’ll spin up 3–4 tailored mini-itineraries (each with a smart flight plan, neighborhood base, daily themes mixing icons + hidden gems, and efficient transport) so you can pick your favorite and we’ll flesh it out.

promptPexTests.testinput:
I want to take a scenic route specifically by train.
origin: Paris
destination: Istanbul
dates: September
budget: flexible
goals: slow travel, photography, local food
transportation_preference: train only
If this creates constraints, ask me how I want to handle timing vs. speed.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love this! A train-only journey from Paris to Istanbul in September is a dream for slow travel, photography, and local food. Because some cross-border legs are slower or have limited frequency, I want to check a few preferences so I tailor the route and pace just right.

Quick questions to shape the perfect plan:
- How many days do you want for the journey (excluding your time in Istanbul)?
- Daytime scenic rides only, or are you open to a few night trains to free up daylight for photography?
- Ideal daily train time: 4–6 hours, 6–8, or 8–10?
- Photography focus: mountains/lakes, river valleys, city architecture, street life/markets, golden hour/blue hour?
- Food focus: markets and street food, coffee/wine stops, regional classics, or fine dining?
- Are you open to scenic detours even if they add a day or two (e.g., Swiss Alps or Transylvania)?
- Train-only can mean choosing slower but prettier routes; how do you want to balance timing vs. scenery?

Three scenic train routes to consider in September (all train-only):
1) Alpine + Danube + Transylvania
   - Paris → Strasbourg → Basel/Lucerne → Zurich → Innsbruck → Salzburg → Vienna → Budapest → Sibiu → Brașov → Bucharest → Sofia → Istanbul (Halkalı)
   - Why it’s gorgeous: Swiss lakes and peaks, Tyrolean Alps, baroque Salzburg, grand Vienna, Danube views, and the Carpathians between Sibiu and Brașov are superb photography territory.
   - Food trail highlights: tarte flambée (Alsace), Swiss cheese/cheese tarts, Tyrolean kaiserschmarrn, Viennese coffee houses, Hungarian goulash and Tokaji, Romanian sarmale and papanasi, Bulgarian banitsa, Turkish meze and simit.
   - Sleeper options that fit slow travel: Paris–Vienna Nightjet; Budapest–Bucharest overnight; Sofia–Istanbul overnight.
   - Pace idea: 9–12 days with 1–2 nights in Lucerne or Innsbruck (for mountains), Vienna or Budapest (for river cityscapes), and a night or two in Transylvania.

2) Northern Italy + Slovenia + Balkans
   - Paris → Lyon → Turin → Milan → Venice → Trieste → Ljubljana → Zagreb → Belgrade → Niš → Sofia → Istanbul
   - Why it’s gorgeous: Alpine crossing to Italy, Venetian lagoons, karst cliffs near Trieste, emerald rivers and leafy hills of Slovenia, Sava valley to Croatia/Serbia, and rugged uplands into Bulgaria.
   - Food trail highlights: Piedmont aperitivo, Milanese risotto, cicchetti in Venice, Slovenian potica, Croatian štrukli, Serbian ćevapi, Bulgarian shopska salad, Turkish baklava and tea culture.
   - Notes: Balkan services can be slower with limited frequency; great for slow travel and candid street photography. Expect 10–14 days depending on how long you linger in Venice, Ljubljana, and Belgrade.

3) Rhine Gorge + Central Europe + Black Sea mountains
   - Paris → Strasbourg → Cologne → Koblenz → Rhine valley (to Mainz/Bingen) → Passau → Vienna → Budapest → Timișoara → Sibiu → Brașov → Bucharest → Plovdiv → Sofia → Istanbul
   - Why it’s gorgeous: The Rhine gorge (castles, vineyards, river bends) is one of Europe’s classic rail-photo corridors; then you get Danube towns and the dramatic Carpathian crossing in Romania, plus Plovdiv’s old town.
   - Food trail highlights: German pretzels and Kölsch, Austrian schnitzel and cake, Hungarian lángos, Romanian mici and covrigi, Bulgarian lyutenitsa and banitsa, Turkish mezes.
   - Pace idea: 10–13 days, with golden-hour runs in the Rhine valley and blue-hour shoots in Budapest.

Photography-friendly timing ideas:
- Aim for late-afternoon arrivals into mountain or river cities (Lucerne/Innsbruck/Vienna/Budapest) and early departures for misty lake/river shots.
- Use sleepers where scenery isn’t the draw (e.g., Budapest–Bucharest, Sofia–Istanbul) to maximize daylight in photogenic spots.

Would you like me to build one of these out day-by-day with specific train numbers, suggested seat reservations, golden/blue-hour windows, and food stops? If so, pick your favorite route and share:
- Total days you want to spend,
- Daytime-only vs. a couple of night trains,
- Your top photo priorities and any “must-eat” foods,
- How you want to handle timing vs. scenery (add days for the prettiest legs, or keep it tighter).

promptPexTests.testinput:
I need gift ideas that can arrive fast.
recipient: dad
occasion: retirement
interests: gardening, jazz vinyl, tinkering
budget: up to $100
location: rural Alaska
shipping_constraint: must arrive within 5 days
Please ask if digital gifts are acceptable.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it—let’s get your dad something awesome that lands within 5 days in rural Alaska. Quick questions first so I can tailor this perfectly:
- Are digital gifts acceptable? Those can arrive instantly and are great insurance for the 5‑day window.
- Does his address accept courier deliveries (UPS/FedEx) or is it PO Box only? That can affect 2–5 day shipping.
- What kind of gardening does he do up there—raised beds, greenhouse, short-season veggies, perennials?
- What “tinkering” lane does he love most—electronics, small engines, woodworking, fixing tools, or general DIY?
- Does he have a specific turntable or any record-care needs right now?
- Would you prefer one standout gift or a mini bundle?

While you think on those, here are fast-arrival ideas under $100. I’ve split them into instant digital and quick-ship physical so you can mix and match.

Instant digital (arrives today)
1) Jazz + DIY combo: Bandcamp digital gift card ($50) for hand-picking jazz albums + Make: magazine digital subscription (about $35–$40) for endless tinkering inspiration. I can create a printable “retirement listening + building” certificate for you to present.
2) Garden planning subscription: GrowVeg Garden Planner (1-year, instant email). Perfect for short-season Alaska layout planning, frost dates, succession planting, and raised beds. Pair with a custom printable garden map with his name.
3) Hardware/electronics fuel: Ace Hardware e‑gift card or Adafruit/SparkFun e‑gift certificate (instant by email). He can grab gardening tools locally or order a fun electronics kit to tinker with indoors.

Fast-ship physical (pick items fulfilled by Amazon and confirm delivery ETA to his zip)
4) Vinyl care starter bundle: Carbon-fiber anti-static record brush + stylus cleaner (like Onzow or Audio-Technica) + a 50-pack of anti-static inner sleeves (MOFI). Small, light, and typically fast to Alaska; perfect for jazz vinyl listening sessions.
5) Seed-starting heat mat with thermostat controller: Helps germinate in cold climates. Add a soil thermometer for an under-$100 greenhouse-friendly starter set.
6) Garden kneeler/seat with tool pouches + quality pruners (Fiskars). Easy on knees and hands—great daily-use retirement gear.
7) Precision toolkit for tinkering: iFixit Mako or a Klein precision screwdriver set + magnetic wristband for holding screws while he works. Compact and usually ships quickly.
8) Headlamp + rechargeable hand warmers combo: For early/late outdoor chores in low light and chilly temps. Lightweight, practical, and fast to ship.

If timing is tight, one smart route is a digital gift today (guaranteed arrival) plus one compact physical add-on with Prime shipping to his exact address.

Anything you want to add or adjust? Tell me if digital gifts are a go, and which idea number you’re leaning toward—I’ll flesh it out, add brand picks, check typical Alaska shipping considerations, and prep a short message you can include with the gift.

promptPexTests.testinput:
Give me ideas for volunteering this weekend.
cause_preferences: environment or hunger relief
availability: Saturday morning or Sunday afternoon
transportation: bike or public transit only
location: unspecified (ask for my city)
skills: basic admin, event setup
I’m open to family-friendly options too.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love this! Let’s find a weekend volunteering plan that fits environment or hunger relief, works with bike/transit, and matches your availability.

Quick questions to tailor this:
- What city (and rough neighborhood) are you in?
- Which slot is better: Saturday morning or Sunday afternoon?
- Do you prefer biking or public transit this weekend? If biking, what’s your comfortable distance?
- Will you bring family/kids? If yes, what ages?
- Do you want outdoor hands-on tasks, indoor/admin, or a mix?

Here are some easy-to-join ideas you can do in most cities. Pick a favorite and I’ll tailor it to specific local orgs and sign-ups.

1) Park or River Cleanup with a Local Conservancy
- Why it fits: Environment impact, very bike/transit friendly, usually Saturday mornings.
- What you’d do: Set up check-in table, hand out gloves/bags, track filled bags, or join the cleanup crew.
- Family-friendly: Yes. Great for kids with adults.

2) Community Garden Workday
- Why it fits: Environment + community food access, usually reachable by transit, often Saturday mornings.
- What you’d do: Event setup, tool station, mulch/weeding, building/repairing raised beds, watering.
- Family-friendly: Often yes (older kids especially).

3) Farmers Market Gleaning + Bike Delivery to Food Pantry or Free Fridges
- Why it fits: Hunger relief with low-waste impact; markets are transit-friendly; deliveries can be bike-based.
- What you’d do: Help collect end-of-market produce, do a short bike run to nearby pantry/free fridges, simple intake logging.
- Timing: Late Saturday morning/noon or Sunday afternoon depending on your local market.
- Family-friendly: Light roles can work if kids are comfortable around markets.

4) Food Bank Sort-and-Pack Shift
- Why it fits: Direct hunger relief; many food banks have Sunday afternoon shifts accessible by transit.
- What you’d do: Check-in support, labeling, sorting produce/canned goods, assembling food boxes.
- Family-friendly: Often yes (with age minimums).

5) Free Fridge Restock + Inventory Helper
- Why it fits: Hyper-local hunger relief; easy to do by bike.
- What you’d do: Source donations from a nearby market or grocery, bike them to a community fridge, basic inventory logging and cleaning.
- Timing: Flexible; Sunday afternoon works well.

6) Meal-Packing Event (e.g., Rise Against Hunger-style)
- Why it fits: Big impact fast; often public transit accessible; usually weekend afternoons.
- What you’d do: Setup tables, manage the packing line, quality checks, cleanup.
- Family-friendly: Usually yes with supervision.

7) Trail, Beach, or Urban Habitat Restoration
- Why it fits: Environment-focused outdoor work; Saturday mornings; many sites on transit lines or reachable by bike.
- What you’d do: Event setup, registration, invasive plant removal, trash pickup, mulching.
- Family-friendly: Often yes.

Want me to find specific opportunities and sign-up links near you? Share your city, weekend slot, and transport preference. If one of these ideas is your favorite, I’ll dive deeper with a plan (exact orgs, how to get there by bike/transit, what to bring, and a quick message you can send to organizers).

promptPexTests.testinput:
Help me with workshop icebreaker ideas that are genuinely good.
group: 25 adults
context: creative writing workshop
duration: 15–20 minutes
goals: loosen up, spark imagination, build trust
materials: pens, paper, projector available
accessibility: include options for participants with mobility or hearing differences
Please check if there’s a theme you should align with.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it! Before I jump in, a couple quick questions to tailor things:
- Is there a specific theme I should align with (genre, season, event focus, or a particular topic)?
- What vibe are you going for—playful, introspective, or a mix?
- Do participants already know each other? Any remote attendees? Any constraints with the room setup (tables, seating style, sound)?

While you think on that, here are five genuinely good, low-pressure icebreakers designed for 25 adults, 15–20 minutes, with options for mobility and hearing differences. All use pens, paper, and the projector.

1) One-Minute Worlds (constraints for instant creativity)
- Why it works: Fast, fun, and low stakes. Everyone writes something, shares by choice, and gets a quick win.
- Setup: Project 10 “word bundles” (2 nouns + 1 emotion). Example: lighthouse, bees, wonder; velvet, suitcase, envy.
- Flow (15–20 min):
  1–2 min: Explain and show bundles on the projector (also hand out a one-line instruction).
  7–8 min: Everyone picks a bundle and writes a 6–8 sentence micro-scene that uses all three words.
  6–8 min: Break into trios. Each person shares either the first 3 lines or a favorite image. Optional: one volunteer per trio reads aloud, or you collect a few and project them.
- Accessibility:
  - Hearing: Put instructions and timing on slides/handouts; pair/trio sharing can be done by exchanging papers instead of speaking; volunteers can have their piece projected rather than read.
  - Mobility: No movement needed; keep people in place. If writing speed varies, offer a shorter option (4 sentences).

2) Safe Secrets in Metaphor (trust without oversharing)
- Why it works: Builds trust gently. People share a “safe” personal detail through metaphor—creative and protective.
- Setup: Project prompt: “Write a metaphor for a harmless secret or writing habit (e.g., ‘I draft in midnight ink’).”
- Flow (15–20 min):
  2 min: Explain what counts as a safe secret; show examples.
  6–8 min: Write 3–5 metaphor lines. Optional twist: add a sensory detail or unusual verb.
  6–8 min: Pair up. Partner guesses the literal habit, then offers one appreciative note (e.g., “I love the image of ‘midnight ink’”).
- Accessibility:
  - Hearing: Instructions and prompts on slides/handouts; partner exchange can be written (swap papers, jot guesses).
  - Mobility: No movement or physical activity required.
  - Safety: Emphasize opting out of guessing or sharing; metaphors allow privacy.

3) Pass-the-Line: Collaborative Microfiction (builds connection through co-creation)
- Why it works: Quick co-writing lowers pressure and builds trust via shared ownership. It sparks imagination with constraints.
- Setup: Project 5 opening lines across different tones. Example: “The package arrived humming.” “She kept dates in three calendars, none of them time.”
- Flow (15–20 min):
  2 min: Form groups of 4–5 where they’re seated. Give each group one opening line on paper.
  8–10 min: Silent pass-the-line. Each person adds one sentence, then passes the page. After 4–5 rounds, stop.
  5–7 min: Groups pick a title and optionally share by projecting a photo of the page or having one person read.
- Accessibility:
  - Hearing: Written collaboration; no need to talk during drafting. Display instructions and a visual timer.
  - Mobility: No movement; pass papers within the group.
  - Comfort: Sharing is optional; you can collect pages and project 2–3 highlights.

4) Stationary Carousel of Constraints (keep bodies still, rotate ideas)
- Why it works: Novel constraints loosen up perfectionism and spark inventive choices. Trust comes from laughing at “rules” together.
- Setup: Prepare 6–8 prompt cards you can pass or project in waves:
  - No adjectives
  - Every sentence is a question
  - Use only one color in all images
  - Include an invented proverb
  - Two sentences only
  - A sound must appear in each sentence
- Flow (15–20 min):
  2 min: Explain: “We’re staying seated; the constraints come to you.”
  12–14 min: In pairs, tackle 3 constraints in short rounds (3–4 min each). After each round, pass the card/stretch your fingers.
  2–4 min: Quick share: each pair reads 1–2 lines from their favorite constraint.
- Accessibility:
  - Hearing: Instructions on slides/handouts; each round’s constraint is visually shown; sharing can be projected or passed around.
  - Mobility: Prompts rotate, not people.
  - Pace: Offer a “lighter” option: single sentence per constraint.

5) Memory Map Mini-Tour (gentle personal connection through place)
- Why it works: Place-based storytelling is vivid and human; maps create instant sensory detail and trust without heavy disclosure.
- Setup: Project simple examples of hand-drawn maps with labeled sensory notes (smell, texture, sound).
- Flow (15–20 min):
  3–4 min: Draw a quick map of a real or imagined place that matters today (kitchen at dawn, ferry deck, childhood tree, invented city).
  6–8 min: Add 5 labels with sensory details and one metaphor (e.g., “floor = piano keys of morning”).
  5–8 min: Pair or trio “mini-tours”: exchange papers and write one line of appreciation on the other’s page.
- Accessibility:
  - Hearing: Tours can be silent by exchanging papers; all instructions projected and printed.
  - Mobility: Entirely seated; drawing and writing only.
  - Comfort: Sharing is via written appreciation, not performance.

Facilitator tips for all five:
- Put all instructions, timing, and examples on slides; use a visible timer.
- Offer opt-in sharing and multiple ways to participate (read aloud, pass papers, project).
- Keep groups small (pairs/trios) to reduce noise and social pressure.
- Provide high-contrast slides and printed prompts for anyone who needs them.

Would you like me to align these to a specific theme (e.g., speculative fiction, nature writing, mystery, seasonal, or a topic your workshop covers)? If you pick one of the ideas, I’ll tailor the prompts, sample openings, and a ready-to-use slide/handout set.

metrics.content:
---
description: "Compare against the groundtruth value if available"
tags:
    - unlisted
    - scorer
inputs:
    prompt:
        type: string
        description: "Chatbot description"
    rules:
        type: string
        description: "The rules to be applied for the test generation"
    input:
        type: string
        description: "The input given to the chatbot"
    output:
        type: string
        description: "Chatbot output"
    groundtruth:
        type: string
        description: "Groundtruth value to compare against"
---
system:
Your task is to very carefully and thoroughly evaluate the given output generated by a chatbot in <CHATBOT_OUTPUT> to find out if it both is correct according the groundtruth value (if available) in <GROUNDTRUTH> and that it complies with its description and the rules that are extracted from the description and provided to you in <RULES>.
Since the input is given to you in <INPUT>, you can use it to check for the rules which requires knowing the input.
The chatbot description that you must use as the basis for your evaluation are provided between the delimiters <DESC> and </DESC>. The description is as follows:

<DESC>
{{prompt}}
</DESC>

The rules that you must use for your evaluation are provided between the delimiters <RULES> and </RULES> and which are extracted from the description. The rules are as follows:
<RULES>
{{rules}}
</RULES>

The input for which the output is generated:
<INPUT>
{{input}}
</INPUT>

The groundtruth value that you must compare the output against (if available):
<GROUNDTRUTH>
{{groundtruth}}
</GROUNDTRUTH>
